data.title: "editor.tabSize" does not change the default indentation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set "editor.tabSize": 2
2. Open a file with two-space width indentation, inserted as spaces
3. Edit any spot in the code, and the indentation gets forced globally to 4 instead of 2 as the tab width

data.title: Clean up the View menu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Win 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  In `View` Menu the first 5 entries (Explorer, Search, Git, Debug, Extensions)  
   are also available on the Side Bar as buttons. 
   The Side Bar itself cannot be hidden, so its 5 buttons are always accessible.
2.  My suggestion is to put the `Command Palette` entry on top of the View menu.  
   This would offer quicker access to Command Palette (which provides access to so many commands)
   ![2016-07-28_233903 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723651/17229059/8a54d00e-551e-11e6-8dfd-3035a0324f86.jpg)

data.title: Fix #9922: Roll back PowerShell syntax definition
data.body: This change rolls back the PowerShell syntax definition file to a previous state before a major refactoring which introduced a lot of new issues.  Once these issues are fixed we will move back to the new definition.

data.title: Roll back to old PowerShell syntax highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: All

For the 1.3.0 release of VS Code we introduced a new syntax file for PowerShell which ended up having a few critical bugs.  Since we keep finding more issues with the new syntax file I think it's probably good to revert back to the old one before finishing the 1.4 release.  I know you're in lock down mode right now, but is there any possibility that we could revert for this release so that users aren't troubled by the issues anymore?

I'll go ahead and submit a PR, feel free to accept or reject based on what you decide.

Thanks!

/cc @aeschli @egamma

data.title: C# preprocessor expressions highlighting is inconsistent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

``` csharp
#if UNIX
            // some code here
#else
            // some code here
#endif
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/816680/17228267/31944fd2-54c7-11e6-9b66-90ef8285e486.png)

It's very inconsistent highlighting:
- `#` is highlighted in the first `#if`, but not elsewhere
- `if`and `else` highlighted (probably as a keywords), but `endif` not

data.title: Environment variables are not passed to debuggee proccess.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.1
- OS Version:10.11.2
- C++ Tools 0.8.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make default Launch C++ debug configuration
2. Run debug and check environment variables
3. Expected result: PATH, HOME etc variables set
4. Expected result: custom variables passed through launch.json set
5. Actual result: any variables aren't passed to debugee process.

data.title: Add API to the picker to keep it open even when focus is lost
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insider 1.4.0
- OS Version: Win 10

There is different behavior I'm facing in VScode insider build. When i open any page in browser and open a input box , after page opens and current window changes automatically to browser the promise for show input box returns undefined.

It is working fine in the current normal build of VSCode

Would you please tell me how to tackle such thing as i think it will go to the current build of VScode.

data.title: Electron conversion to appx (for Windows Store)?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Any
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update

Electron has recently released guidelines on convert Electron applications to .appx file, and therefore compatible with the Windows Store here: http://electron.atom.io/docs/tutorial/windows-store-guide/

Will VSCode be converted to an appx for Windows Store? I honestly think it would be a good investment as after all this is by Microsoft.

data.title: JavaScript IntelliSense is not working without jsconfig.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: El Capitan

**No IntelliSense without jsconfig.json**
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code on a simple JavaScript project without jsconfig.json. 
2. Trigger Suggest on a first party module. I expect to see IntelliSense even without a jsconfig.json file. 

I am not seeing IntelliSense for my first party module. It is stuck loading. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/17222878/1abb3e1e-54af-11e6-8062-b13ebee7c3c5.png)

I am not seeing any IntelliSense. It will load endlessly. I would expect to at least get basic code completion. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/17222899/31a71e2c-54af-11e6-9cee-2a2a7244fdf5.png)

After adding jsconfig with the simplest of configuration and reloaded the window (this was important, it would not work if I didn't reload the window nor would it work if I reloaded the JavaScript project). 

```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES6",
    "module": "commonjs"
  }
}
```

IntelliSense is working again. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/17223037/b5926c82-54af-11e6-83cc-0af05d1dd7c6.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/17222995/8a38dd5a-54af-11e6-87b6-820005d2cac9.png)

Is this the intended behavior? 

I would expect to at least get basic code completion with no jsconfig.json file. Also I would expect to be given a hint to add a jsconfig.json file (see issue #9875) if it isn't there already.

data.title: Javascript - Go to definition does not work with variables (sublime does so VSC should too)
incorrect JS highlight with lower than operator and semicolon in for loop condition
JSDoc Support - Optional Parameters Ignored
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Annotate a class constructor with an optional parameter
2. Attempt to invoke the constructor with the optional parameter excluded
3. Intellisense does not provide code completion for the object without the optional parameter present

``` javascript
/**
* @param {string} bar - A required string
* @param {string} [baz] - An optional string
*/
function Foo(bar, baz) {
    this.bar = bar;
    this.baz = baz === void 0 ? '' : baz;
}
new Foo('bar', 'baz'). // Intellisense provided
new Foo('bar'). // Intellisense not provided
```

data.title: shift+cmd+3 is not performing sort descending operation on lines
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4 insiders (6ef86d5f85a531caa59bfb1715469fcfaa8d2efd)
- OS Version:OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Select some lines in a file and type <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>3</kbd>

Expected: Lines should be sorted descending
Actual: Nothing happens

**Note:** Sort descending happens if select the command from pallette. Also <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>2</kbd> works properly.

data.title: showInputBox overrides with initial value after provided an invalid value and clearing it
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4 insiders
- OS Version:OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

``` typescript
export function activate(activationContext: vscode.ExtensionContext) {
  vscode.window.showInputBox({
    value: 'initial-value',
    validateInput: (text: string) => text=='' ? '' : 'input must be empty'
  });
}
```
1. run the above extension
2. type a character into the input box
3. this will trigger validation failure
4. Clear the input
5. **bug**: Initial value appears (not expected IMO)
6. Put some valid value and clear it
7. Initial value does not appear (makes sense)

data.title: Close the extension resource in the editor if it is filtered in the view
data.body:
- Open Extension view
- Select any installed extension
- Filter for most popular extensions, make sure that selected is not part of these

Since selected extension is no longer available, it makes sense to close the resource too.

data.title: add highlighting of common keywords like TODO
data.body:
hi,

i'm submitting a feature request.
it would be nice to have color highlighting of common keywords like TODO, FIXME, XXX et cetera.

data.title: JS intellisense from a typings file only works after restarting VS Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder with an empty .js file inside it
2. Install lodash - npm install --save lodash
3. Install the typings file for lodash - typings install lodash
4. Add a jsconfig.json file
5. In the .js file, use lodash - 
   var _ = require('lodash');
   _.
6. Expected: Intellisense to show up as soon as typing '_. '
   Actual: only simple word based intellisense shows up

I needed to close and then reopen VS Code to get intellisense working properly.

data.title: Support composite Undo

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.title: Transient breakpoint flickers when running `Run to cursor` action

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In #8731, there was a fix to not show a breakpoint once the `Run to Cursor` action is run. It works, but the current behaviour is fidgety: the breakpoint is still seen for a split second only to disappear in a sea of flickering.

Maybe we should have different _types_ of breakpoints: explicit (user set) and implicit (service set)?
